subject: Re: [junit] running test methods in order
msgSnippet: I have used it. It s a great tool to use when you need it, but it s important to refactor away from it, eventually. OrderedTestSuite allows you to specify the
messageBody:
I have used it. It's a great tool to use when you need it, but it's
important to refactor away from it, eventually.

OrderedTestSuite allows you to specify the order of some tests and let
the rest execute in whatever order. I used it this way:

1. I had tests that were order-dependent.
2. I figured out which tests had to go first. I let the rest go in any
order.
3. I refactored the order-dependent tests until they were independent.
4. I removed the OrderedTestSuite.

For Programmer Tests, you should never need it and must refactor away
from it. For Customer Tests, it is very useful.

Thanks.

So said tek1 on 2003-01-29 --------------------

>haven't used it yet, but found this the other day:
>
>http://gsbase.sourceforge.net/
>
>scroll down on the page until you see "OrderedTestSuite".
>
>
>
>At 07:43 03/01/29 -0600, you wrote:
>
>>First off, you can control the order by explicitly setting up a
>>TestSuite in a suite() method in the TestCase.
>>
>>That being said, I wouldn't introduce the order dependency in running
>>the tests for unit/programmer tests. It sounds like your somewhere
>>in between a unit tests and a integration tests since you may be
>>depending on the external database, so...
>>
>>If writing the suite method yourself doesn't sound like a good
option,
>>you could just move this into one testXXX() and do the two inserts
>>and check in the test that the second fails, then clean up the
>>inserted record in tearDown().
>>
>>"belingueres <gaby@...>" <gaby@...> writes:
>>
>> > Hi,
>> >
>> > I need to test a simple insertion of a tuple into a data base
table.
>> >
>> > First I set the table empty, then I test that an specific tuple is
>> > correctly inserted.
>> > Then, I try to insert the same tuple again, which would result in
an
>> > exception, since its primary key is duplicated.
>> >
>> > Those tow tests I did it in two different testXXX() methods in the
>> > TestCase: testInsert() and testDuplicated()
>> >
>> > The thing is that JUnit runs first the testDuplicated() method and
>> > then the testInsert(), so the two tests fails!
>> >
>> > How can I assure myself that the two test methods run in a
particular
>> > order?
>> >
>> > Is this a good testing practice?
>> >
>> > Thanks in advance,
>> > Gabriel
>>
>>
>>--
>>=====================================================================
>>Jeffrey D. Brekke jbrekke@...
>>Wisconsin, USA brekke@...
